questions.text: A 22 year old female came to the casualty with complaints of breathlessness which is gradually increasing with difficulty in lying down. On examination she has mid diastolic murmur with opening snap. She had a history of joint pain and fever in the past for which she is receiving inj. Penicillin. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral stenosis Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. In rheumatic mitral stenosis, chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening of the valve leaflets with formation of fibrous tissue often with calcific deposits. Mitral stenosis: in the above case there is history of rheumatic fever and joint pain in the past. Now, the pt had breathlessness and on auscultation there is presence of opening snap. This is suggestive of mitral stenosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Atrial septal defect: in atrial septal defect, there is wide and fixed splitting of second heart sound Option: C. Tricuspid regurgitation: in tricuspid regurgitation there is presence of pansystolic murmur.

questions.text: A 30 years old female came to the casualty with complaints of breathlessness and history of fever and joint pain in the past. On auscultation there is mid diastolic murmur. What is the correct statement in the above case?

options.label: A
options.text: If A2 and opening snap gap increases the disease become severe

options.label: B
options.text: If A2 and opening snap gap decreases the disease become severe

options.label: C
options.text: A2 and opening snap gap has no correlation

questions.correct_answer: B. If A2 and opening snap gap decreases the disease become severe
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If A2 and opening snap gap decreases the disease become severe Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. In rheumatic mitral stenosis, chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening of the valve leaflets with formation of fibrous tissue often with calcific deposits . The elevated pulmonary venous and pulmonary arterial wedge pressure reduce pulmonary compliance contributing to exertional dyspnea. On auscultation the s1 sound is usually accentuated in early stages. P2 is The opening snap of the mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration. The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with severity of ms. A2 and opening snap gap decreases the disease becoming severe: the opening snap of mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration. The time interval between a2 and os varies inversely with severity of ms. Henceforth, the interval between a2 and os decreases the severity increases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A2 and opening snap gap increases the disease become severe: the time interval between a2 and os varies inversely with severity of ms. Henceforth, the interval between a2 and os decreases the severity increases. Option: C. A2 and opening snap gap has no correlation : the time interval between a2 and os varies inversely with severity of ms.

questions.text: A 28 years old male came to the casualty with complaints of chest pain and breathlessness, but had a history of joint pain and fever for which he was treated for a long time. What will be the findings of this pt on auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A & B Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis . In rheumatic mitral stenosis, chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening of the valve leaflets with formation of fibrous tissue often with calcific deposits. The elevated pulmonary venous and pulmonary arterial wedge pressure reduce pulmonary compliance contributing to exertional dyspnea. On auscultation the s1 sound is usually accentuated in early stages. P2 is accentuated. The opening snap of the mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration. The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with severity of MS. There is presence of mid diastolic murmur. Both a and b: in mitral stenosis, there is presence of both mid diastolic murmur and opening snap.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A . Mid diastolic murmur : in mitral stenosis there is presence of mid diastolic murmur. Option B . Opening snap: the opening snap of mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration. The time interval between a2 and os varies inversely with severity of ms.

questions.text: A 40 years female with a history of breathlessness, on examination there is presence of mid diastolic murmur. Her echocardiography was performed: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral stenosis In mitral stenosis, the mitral commissures fuse, the chordae tendineae fuse and shorten, the valvular cusps become rigid and the pathologic process eventually leads to narrowing at the apex of the funnel shaped(fish mouth)valve. There is presence of mid diastolic murmur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Atrial septal defect : in atrial septal defect, there is wide and fixed splitting of second heart sound. Option: C. Tricuspid regurgitation: in tricuspid regurgitation there is presence of pansystolic murmur.

questions.text: A 40 years old male with a history of mitral stenosis now came to the hospital with complaints of hemoptysis. What is the underlying mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Pulmonary-bronchial venous connection secondary to pulmonary hypertension

questions.correct_answer: A. Pulmonary-bronchial venous connection secondary to pulmonary hypertension
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary-bronchial venous connection secondary to pulmonary hypertension The elevated pulmonary venous and pulmonary arterial wedge pressure reduce pulmonary compliance contributing to exertional dyspnea. Pulmonary-bronchial venous connection secondary to pulmonary hypertension: in mitral stenosis , there is presence of pulmonary bronchial venous connection secondary to pulmonary hypertension.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Esophageal varices: this condition is more common in alcoholic cirrhosis pt with portal hypertension. Option: C. Pulmonary cavitary lesions; this is common in pulmonary tuberculosis pt.

questions.text: A 30 years female with history of mitral stenosis , on examination carvallo's sign was noticed. What is the carvallo sign?

options.label: A
options.text: Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during inspiration and diminished during forced expiration

options.label: B
options.text: Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during expiration and diminished during inspiration

questions.correct_answer: A. Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during inspiration and diminished during forced expiration
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during inspiration and diminished during forced expiration This is seen in Mitral stenosis, due to pulmonary hypertension.Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during inspiration and diminished during forced expiration;carvallo’s sign is seen in mitral stenosis with severe pulmonary hypertension leading to functional tricuspid regurgitation. In this case the murmur becomes louder during inspiration and diminishes during forced expiration .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Functional tricuspid regurgitation murmur louder during expiration and diminished during inspiration: in this case the murmur become louder during inspiration and diminishes during forced expiration.

questions.text: A 40 year old male came to the casualty complaining of breathlessness with a history of weight loss and fever. There is presence of diastolic murmur on examination and increased in il-6 and igG. The echo shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left atrial myxoma Left atrial myxoma is differentials of mitral stenosis. In left atrial myxoma there is obstruction of left atrium emptying leading to dyspnea and diastolic murmur resembling that of mitral stenosis . But in left atrial myxoma there is presence of systemic features like fever , weight loss, anemia, systemic emboli , raised igg and il-6.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Mitral stenosis: presence of systemic features like fever , weight loss, anemia, systemic emboli , raised igg and il-6 is not common in mitral stenosis. Option: C. Atrial septal defect : in atrial septal defect, there is wide and fixed splitting of second heart sound.

questions.text: A 35 years male with history of mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation with controlled rate and hemodynamically stable, planned for cardioversion. Which is the correct statement?

options.label: B
options.text: Pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion

options.label: C
options.text: Pt should be started on anticoagulation 2 weeks prior to the cardioversion

questions.correct_answer: B. Pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion Pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion: in mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation, if pt is hemodynamically stable, pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion to prevent thromboembolic event.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Immediately cardiovert the pt: pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion to prevent thromboembolic event. No need for immediate cardioversion as pt is hemodynamically stable. Option: C. Pt should be started on anticoagulation 2 weeks prior to the cardioversion: in mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation, if pt is hemodynamically stable, pt should be started on anticoagulation 3 weeks prior to the cardioversion to prevent thromboembolic event.

questions.text: A 33 year old female with a history of gradual increase in breathlessness and difficulty in sleeping due to breathlessness was diagnosed as severe mitral stenosis. Her echo suggestive of valve area of 1cm2, with no calcified cusp, there are mobile and absence of mitral regurgitation. What is the best line of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Balloon mitral valvotomy Balloon mitral valvotomy: in this case the pt is symptomatic hence there is need of intervention. The echo finding suggestive of favorable valves suggesting mobile leaflets with no calcification and mitral regurgitation. Hence, balloon mitral valvotomy is a preferred procedure .

Highyeild:

The treatment protocol of mitral stenosis is:

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Mitral valve replacement: mitral valve replacement is recommended in symptomatic pt with a severe calcified valve with moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Option: C . Observation: as the pt is symptomatic we cant put pt under observation.

questions.text: A 23 year old male came to the hospital for a routine checkup. Incidentally on echocardiography it was found that the mitral area is 1. 2 cm2 with normal pulmonary artery pressure. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Observation Observation: as the pt is asymptomatic at present, there is no need for any intervention. Pt should advise follow up.

Highyeild:

The treatment protocol of mitral stenosis is:

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Balloon mitral valvotomy: it is preferred in symptomatic pt with favorable valvular pathology. Option: B. Mitral valve replacement: it is preferred in symptomatic pt with unfavorable valvular pathology.

questions.text: Mrs. Kavita, an 84-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of shortness of breath with severe mitral stenosis who is scheduled for percutaneous mitral balloon valvotomy in 3 days. On evaluation, she appears dyspneic and in mild distress. Oxygen saturation in room air is 91%, heart rate is 55 beats/min, and blood pressure is 110/80. She has rales to the mid-lung fields bilaterally. You note that her rhythm is irregularly irregular, and an electrocardiogram confirms the new onset of atrial fibrillation. You suspect that she has a very high left atrial pressure causing pulmonary edema. All of the following therapeutic interventions will help lower her left atrial pressure EXCEPT:

options.label: D
options.text: Transvenous pacemaker placement and pacing at a heart rate of 90 beats/min

questions.correct_answer: D. Transvenous pacemaker placement and pacing at a heart rate of 90 beats/min
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transvenous pacemaker placement and pacing at a heart rate of 90 beats/min The left atrial to left ventricular pressure gradient is highly dependent on heart rate since diastolic duration is inversely related to heart rate. In the setting of mitral stenosis, a long diastolic time allows more time for the left atrium to empty, and thus lower pressures. Hence, sinus bradycardia is advantageous in the setting of mitral stenosis, and inducing a faster heart rate via pacemaker would be harmful. The loss of atrial systole during atrial fibrillation is often poorly tolerated in mitral stenosis, and regaining sinus rhythm would undoubtedly lower atrial pressure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. However, the vast majority of patients with mitral stenosis are unable to maintain sinus rhythm long term as their atria tend to be very dilated. Option: A, D. - Diuretics and percutaneous mitral valvotomy will lower left atrial pressure.

questions.text: You are examining Mr. Sunil who is a 56-year-old man with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis. During the exercise test, he complains of shortness of breath. All of the following physiologic parameters will increase during his exercise test EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diastolic filling time The physiology of mitral stenosis leads to a high symptom dependence on heart rate and metabolic demands. As the heart rate climbs with exercise, diastolic filling time declines. Thus, transit time for blood to flow across the stenosed mitral valve is reduced and both left atrial pressure and mitral valve gradient increase.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, D. As left atrial pressure rises, so do “upstream” pressures such as the pulmonary artery pressure. Option: C. As the left atrial and pulmonary artery pressures rise and the pulmonary vasculature is increasingly distended, both pulsatile and nonpulsatile pulmonary vascular resistance load rises.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with an episode of syncope immediately after playing basketball. He has experienced mild dyspnea on exertion over the past 2 months. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 175/90 mm Hg, his carotid pulse is bounding, and there is an early systolic click immediately followed by a late peaking 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. There is no dynamic increase in murmur intensity with the Valsalva maneuver and no change in the timing of the click with squatting. The apical impulse is sustained. A radial femoral delay is suspected on examination. What should be the next step in the evaluation or management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Computed tomographic (CT) scan of the chest

options.label: D
options.text: Reassurance with recommendations for warm-up and cooldown routines with exertion

questions.correct_answer: C. Computed tomographic (CT) scan of the chest
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Computed tomographic (CT) scan of the chest The patient, with a systolic click murmur in the absence of dynamic change, likely has bicuspid aortic valve (AV) stenosis. The diagnosis is more commonly associated with a coarctation of the aorta whose flow murmur is best heard over the posterior aspect between the shoulder blades, slightly to the left of the midline. In the presence of hypertension and radial-femoral delay , there is enough evidence on examination to support imaging of the aorta to rule out coarctation. A CT scan (or magnetic resonance imaging) of the chest would show the coarctation .

Highyeild:

Another appropriate test would be transthoracic echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis of a bicuspid AV and to assess the degree of aortic stenosis. Echocardiography is often used to view the descending thoracic aorta to determine the degree of coarctation; however, if the aorta is not well visualized by echocardiography, other imaging is indicated to rule out the coarctation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B. A coronary angiogram or Holter monitor is unlikely to be helpful unless it is coupled with an aortogram, which might provide the diagnosis, but there may be an increased danger due to the potential for coarctation, which could be difficult to cross with the catheter. This patient most likely does not have coronary artery disease. The murmur and clinical presentation are not benign, and a thorough evaluation is warranted. This patient’s syncopal event is related to aortic stenosis or coarctation with significant stenosis and the inability to adequately increase cardiac output, especially with postexercise vasodilatation.

questions.text: A 26 yrs female came to the casualty with complaints of breathlessness on exertion, but had a history of joint pain and fever for which he was treated for a long time. What could be the possible findings of this patient on auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above All of the above are possible findings

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Mid diastolic murmur:In mitral stenosis there is presence of mid diastolic murmur. Option: B. Opening snap: The opening snap of mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration.The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with severity of MS. Option: C. Accentuation of P2 :due to development of pulmonary hypertension in case of long standing mitral stenosis.
